what: Issue 1: Division by Zero in HSL Hue Calculation
title: Detailed Technical Issues in PRs
text: Location: R/hsl_conversion.R:89-94 (PR #3) Problem: achromatic colors (white, black, grays), delta = maxc - minc = 0. division delta creates Inf NaN values, overwritten line 94. final result correct, inefficient cause issues R’s behavior changes. Recommended Fix: Impact: Low (final result correct), indicates code quality issue.
code: hue_base[red_is_max] <- ((g[red_is_max] - b[red_is_max]) / delta[red_is_max]) %% 6 hue_base[green_is_max] <- ((b[green_is_max] - r[green_is_max]) / delta[green_is_max]) + 2 hue_base[blue_is_max] <- ((r[blue_is_max] - g[blue_is_max]) / delta[blue_is_max]) + 4  h <- (hue_base * 60) %% 360 h[delta == 0] <- 0  # Override AFTER division # Option 1: Guard before division hue_base <- numeric(length(hex_std)) chromatic <- delta != 0  if (any(chromatic)) {   hue_base[chromatic & red_is_max] <- ((g - b) / delta)[chromatic & red_is_max] %% 6   # ... etc }  # Option 2: Use ifelse hue_base[red_is_max] <- ifelse(delta[red_is_max] == 0, 0,                                 ((g[red_is_max] - b[red_is_max]) / delta[red_is_max]) %% 6)

code: # R users expect this to work: hsl_to_hex(0, 1, c(0.25, 0.5, 0.75))  # 3 lightness values, single h and s # Error: h, s, l, and alpha must have compatible lengths # Base R example: paste0(c("a", "b", "c"), 1)  # Works: "a1" "b1" "c1" n <- length(h) if (!(length(s) == n && length(l) == n && (length(alpha) == 1 || length(alpha) == n))) {   stop("h, s, l, and alpha must have compatible lengths") } n <- max(length(h), length(s), length(l)) h_vals <- rep_len(as.numeric(h), n) s_vals <- rep_len(as.numeric(s), n) l_vals <- rep_len(as.numeric(l), n) alpha_vals <- rep_len(as.numeric(alpha), n)

what: Issue 3: Performance Issue in Fallback Function
title: Detailed Technical Issues in PRs
text: Location: R/fallback_nearest_hex.R:35-39 (PR #5) Problem: 32,462 colors converted every call, extremely inefficient. Benchmark: Recommended Fix: Pre-compute LAB values building color table: compute cache: Impact: High - 100x+ performance improvement possible.
code: # Called EVERY time the function runs: hex_lab <- farver::decode_colour(hex, to = "lab")           # O(m) - input ref_lab <- farver::decode_colour(color_table$hex, to = "lab")  # O(32,462) - ALL colors! # Current: ~1.77ms per lookup (mostly spent converting reference colors) # With pre-computed LAB: ~0.01ms per lookup (estimate) # In data-raw/prepare_color_data.R or similar: color_data$lab_l <- farver::decode_colour(color_data$hex, to = "lab")[, 1] color_data$lab_a <- farver::decode_colour(color_data$hex, to = "lab")[, 2] color_data$lab_b <- farver::decode_colour(color_data$hex, to = "lab")[, 3] .lab_cache <- new.env(parent = emptyenv())  get_ref_lab <- function(color_table) {   cache_key <- digest::digest(color_table$hex)   if (!exists(cache_key, .lab_cache)) {     .lab_cache[[cache_key]] <- farver::decode_colour(color_table$hex, to = "lab")   }   .lab_cache[[cache_key]] }

title: Detailed Technical Issues in PRs
text: Location: R/fallback_nearest_hex.R (PR #5) Problem: LAB space, “gray100” (#FFFFFF) “white” (#FFFFFF) identical, due color database structured, may slightly different entries search finds “gray100” first. Root Cause: function doesn’t check exact matches computing distances. hex code exists database, return name directly. Recommended Fix: Impact: Medium - causes confusing results users.
code: hex_to_color("#FFFFFF")        # Returns "white" (exact match) fallback_nearest_hex("#FFFFFF") # Returns "gray100" (nearest by LAB distance) fallback_nearest_hex <- function(hex, color_table = get_color_data()) {   # ... validation ...    # Check exact matches first   hex_upper <- toupper(hex)   exact_matches <- match(hex_upper, toupper(color_table$hex))    result <- character(length(hex))   has_exact <- !is.na(exact_matches)   result[has_exact] <- color_table$name[exact_matches[has_exact]]    # Only compute LAB distances for non-exact matches   if (any(!has_exact)) {     # ... existing LAB distance code for !has_exact indices ...   }    result }

what: Issue 5: Floating Point Noise on Achromatic Colors
title: Detailed Technical Issues in PRs
text: Location: OKLAB/OKLCH functions (PRs #2, #4) Problem: white (grays), b exactly 0, OKLCH chroma 0. tiny values (10^-8 10^-11) floating point noise matrix transformations. Happens: transformation matrices many decimal places: multiplied, tiny rounding errors accumulate. Recommended Fix (Optional): document behavior: Impact: Low - cosmetic issue, doesn’t affect functionality.
code: hex_to_oklab("#FFFFFF") #         L            a            b     alpha # 1.0000000 8.095286e-11 3.727391e-08 1.0000000  hex_to_oklch("#FFFFFF") #          l           c          h     alpha #  1.0000000 3.727400e-08 89.8755600 1.0000000 m2 <- matrix(c(   0.2104542553, 0.7936177850, -0.0040720468,   # ... )) # Round very small values to zero threshold <- 1e-10 a[abs(a) < threshold] <- 0 b[abs(b) < threshold] <- 0 #' @details #' Note: Due to floating point precision, achromatic colors (white, black, grays) #' may return very small non-zero values for a and b components (typically < 1e-8). #' These are effectively zero for all practical purposes.

what: Issue 6: OKLCH Hue for Achromatic Colors
title: Detailed Technical Issues in PRs
text: Location: R/oklch_conversion.R:112 (PR #2) Problem: achromatic colors ≈ 0 b ≈ 0, atan2(0, 0) returns 0, floating point noise means get atan2(3.7e-8, 8.1e-11) gives h ≈ 89.88°. mathematically valid (chroma 0, hue undefined), confusing users. Recommended Fix: Impact: Low - cosmetic, improves user experience.
code: h <- (atan2(b_vals, a) * 180 / pi) %% 360 c_val <- sqrt(a^2 + b_vals^2) h <- (atan2(b_vals, a) * 180 / pi) %% 360 h[c_val < 1e-10] <- 0  # Undefined hue → set to 0
